verse: Abijah, the son of Rehoboam and Micaiah (daughter of Uriel of Gibeah), became king over Judah during Jeroboam’s 18th year as king of the Northern Kingdom. He ruled for 3 years from Jerusalem and battled against Jeroboam.
Abijah, who initiated the war, had an army of 400,000 heroic men, but he was drastically outnumbered by Jeroboam’s army of 800,000 heroic men.
Abijah stood on Mount Zemaraim, which is in the hill country of Ephraim, and addressed Jeroboam and all of the soldiers from the Northern Kingdom.
Yet Jeroboam, Nebat’s son and the servant of David’s son Solomon, rebelled against his master.

During Abijah’s appeal to the Northern Israelites, Jeroboam was not paying attention. Instead, he was dividing his forces into two fronts—one to meet Judah in front of them and one to ambush them from the rear.

When Judah realized what the Northern forces had done, the men shouted to the Eternal and the priests blew their signal trumpets just as Abijah promised. God was faithful to His promise; He crushed Jeroboam and his forces. As they fled, the True God gave the victory over Israel to Abijah and Judah.
Abijah and his army slaughtered 500,000 of the Israelite warriors.
The Northern Israelites were defeated because the people of Judah trusted in the Eternal One, the True God of their ancestors.
Abijah pursued the fleeing Jeroboam and captured several Northern cities and their surrounding towns and regions: Bethel (one of the Northern Kingdom’s shrine cities), Jeshanah, and Ephron.
Jeroboam was weakened by his battles with Judah, and he never regained his former strength. The Eternal struck him, and Jeroboam died.
But Abijah’s strength increased, and he married 14 wives and fathered 22 sons and 16 daughters.
The actions of Abijah, his works and his words, are recorded in the chronicles of Iddo the prophet.
